Docs.summary: This class represents the group membership of an operating system user.

remarks.para: The WindowsPrincipal class can also be used on POSIX compliant operating system.

Docs.param: The identity for which the principal will be created.
Docs.summary: Creates the corresponding principal of a WindowsIdentity instance.
The operating system identity associated with the current principal.
Docs.value: The current identity of the principal.
Docs.remarks: The returned identity will always be a instance.

Docs.summary: Return the membership of the current principal in the specified role.
Docs.returns: True if the current identity is a member of the specified role, false otherwise.
Docs.remarks:
The role id, is mapped like this:

545BUILTIN\\Users
546BUILTIN\\Guests

Docs.summary: Return the membership of the current principal in the specified role.
Docs.returns: True if the current identity is a member of the specified role, false otherwise.
Docs.remarks: On POSIX compliant systems the group is mapped to the "root" group. All other groups will return false.

Docs.summary: Return the membership of the current principal in the specified role.
Docs.returns: True if the current identity is a member of the specified role, false otherwise.
Docs.remarks:
On Unix systems, the role is mapped to Unix groups. For users to be considered to have a certain role, the role must be listed in the Unix groups (the /etc/group file) and it must contain a list of users that belong to that group.
For example, if you want to check that the user is in role "USAGNT\\UGR_RBP" the file /etc/group should contain a line like this:
USAGNT\UGR_RBP:x:300:miguel,don,jon,julia
In this particular example, the users miguel, don, jon and julia belong to the "USAGNT\UGR_RBP" role.
